[Applause] all righty a tavern floor so lots of
people have asked me about doing this and so I thought you get a three by
three tile you can use any size tile but what are we gonna do with this are we
gonna build a whole new tile you know that's a lot of work so I thought no no
you've seen this before we're gonna get a cardboard box that's really thin it's
corrugated but super thin so you can see sort of how thin it is it's almost like
cardstock but it is a corrugated box you can see the corrugation so we're just
gonna get a piece it's about the same size as the actual dungeon tile and
we're going to cut off all the extra floppy bits the flappy bits and measure
the inside of the walls of the tiles which on this one is 18 centimeters and
we're gonna mark out those on the various sides of this cardboard and
we're going to cut that out using our craft knife now we've shown you tile
inserts before but what's going to be more interesting on here is how do we
make it look like a wooden floor so hold on to your hats we're gonna be going in
so check the tile sizes measure it trim it down
check it dry fit it to the tile see if it's six this one's a little bit big
here it's not pushing down to the bottom so it's you're gonna trim off like about
one millimeter on 2 of the sides or sides that are perpendicular to one
another drop it in there now it's fitting fine so now we can get on to the
interesting part you'll see here's everything just fitting in nicely grab
yourself an old toothbrush now or on earth are we doing so brown paint dip
the toothbrush into the brown paint and then just run it across the cardboard in
the same direction as the corrugation and just continue with boots of speed
I'm just using dark brown paint ochre paint and I'm mixing a little bit of
yellow doing the same thing and just continue on always in the same direction
do not change directions always left and right do not switch it up and down I add
a little bit of white and continue over that and switch back
to brown etc etc and then I'm going to get some black heavily watered down so
it's probably about two parts water to one part black and then just you
free-handing drawing lines that are yeah probably about half a centimeter two
centimeter apart you can determine the width that's up to you and just continue
that across the board it doesn't matter if it's not a hundred percent straight
that's not the point the point is you wanted a little rustic look you know I
wanted to look modern so once you've done that you can then begin to just do
some perpendicular lines to show where the sort of joints in the floor are and
use two maximum three lines per for the level and just stagger them all over the
show so they're not an irregular pattern and you can also add in the little knots
of wood if you want to embellish it as you go and as you can see this is very
very simple so the toothbrushes are the thing that's
gonna give you that sort of the grain of the wood look and then obviously there's
watered down paint once it's dry it's not so dark and that gives you the edges
of the of the the wooden floor slanting suppose it's called was not tiles if
you've got any sort of excess they just smooth it over with your finger it'll
kind of look like some aged and rotten pieces so that's okay and there you have
it that's a nice and easy throw on some furniture stick it in the tile and they
have it nice and simple you don't need to go and reconstruct everything you've
got the walls you've got the tile you've got all the furniture and all that kind
